column1: In Burlington, Vt., nearly everyone has a Bernie Sanders impression.
Hearing Bernie Sanders, a Brooklyn native, the writer was reminded of his father.
Mr. Sanders excoriates the impact of racism in society.
Anyone, he says, should be able to run for office without begging wealthy donors for money.

In Iowa on Sunday, Mr. Sanders spoke of Mr. David’s impersonation of him on Saturday Night Live: “I think we’re gonna put him up on the stage at our next rally – let him do it, rather than me. He does it better than I do.”
As Mr. Sanders prepared for a major rally in Nevada on Sunday, an aide to the candidate confirmed that Jim Farrell, his state director there, would not continue in his role.
He doesn’t have one, doesn’t want one, and doesn’t need one.
He gives the crowd a lesson in the Republican definition of family values.
He wants investment in education, not incarceration.
A reader writes that Senator Bernie Sanders’s embrace of that label “may be paying off in the short run.”
